communications.communication:
Village of Hanover Park, IL ************************************************************************ Your record request #24-449 has been submitted successfully. Thank you for contacting the Village of Hanover Park with your request for information pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act. The Freedom of Information Officer for the Village of Hanover Park has determined that your request for records is approved for release.  If you were denied records. You have the right to have the denial of your request reviewed by the Public Access Counselor (PAC) at the Office of the Illinois Attorney General. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). You can file your Request for Review with the PAC by writing to:  Leah Bartlett, Public Access Counselor Office of the Illinois Attorney General 500 South 2nd Street Springfield IL 62701 Public.access@ilag.gov 877-299-3642  You also have the right to seek judicial review of your denial by the Circuit Court of Cook, County, Illinois.  If you choose to file a Request for Review with the PAC, you must do so within 60 calendar days of the date of this denial letter. 5 ILCS 140/9.5(a). Please note that you must include a copy of your original FOIA request and this denial letter when filing a Request for Review with the PAC.  Sincerely, Kristy Merrill  Village Clerk    ************************************************************************ Reply to this email or sign in to contact Village of Hanover Park, IL .

title: Duncan Socrates Lemp Shooting on March 12, 2020

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Duncan Socrates Lemp Shooting on March 12, 2020
communications.communication:
Subject: Comprehensive FOIA Request for Records Related to Duncan Socrates Lemp Shooting on March 12, 2020

To: Montgomery County State’s Attorney’s Office
Montgomery County Circuit Court
50 Maryland Ave.
Rockville, MD 20850

Dear Records Access Officer,

This is a formal request under the Maryland Public Information Act (MPIA) to access all records related to the shooting of Duncan Socrates Lemp on March 12, 2020. As an investigative journalist, I seek these records to ensure public transparency and accountability regarding this significant incident.

Requested Records:

	1.	Body Camera Footage:
	•	All recordings from body-worn cameras of officers present at the scene on March 12, 2020.
	•	Legal Support: ACLU v. Alvarez, 679 F.3d 583 (7th Cir. 2012) affirms the public’s right to record public officials, supporting the disclosure of body camera footage.
	2.	Audio and Video Recordings:
	•	Any additional audio or video recordings, including dashboard camera footage and surveillance footage.
	•	Legal Support: Scott v. United States, 436 U.S. 128 (1978) underscores the public interest in accessing law enforcement communications and recordings for transparency.
	3.	Incident Reports:
	•	All written reports, memos, and briefing documents concerning the shooting incident.
	•	Legal Support: Department of Justice v. Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, 489 U.S. 749 (1989) supports the disclosure of law enforcement records.
	4.	Operational Plans:
	•	Documents detailing strategies and guidelines used by law enforcement during the operation on March 12, 2020.
	•	Legal Support: NLRB v. Robbins Tire & Rubber Co., 437 U.S. 214 (1978) emphasizes the public’s right to understand strategic public authority operations.
	5.	Communications:
	•	All emails, text messages, and other forms of communication among officers, between officers and superiors, and with other relevant parties regarding the incident.
	•	Legal Support: Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Commerce, 34 F. Supp. 2d 28 (D.D.C. 1998) supports the release of communications to ensure transparency in government operations.
	6.	Evidence:
	•	Any evidence collected at the scene, including photographs, physical evidence logs, and forensic reports.
	•	Legal Support: Electronic Frontier Foundation v. Department of Transportation, 2015 confirms that surveillance footage and related evidence are subject to disclosure under FOIA.
	7.	Details of the No-Knock Warrant and Red Flag Law:
	•	All records, including affidavits, applications, and approvals, related to the decision to serve a no-knock warrant under the Red Flag Law prior to the incident on March 12, 2020.
	•	Legal Support: Giglio v. United States, 405 U.S. 150 (1972) establishes the requirement for the disclosure of exculpatory evidence and details about procedural actions taken by law enforcement.
	•	Legal Support: Illinois v. Gates, 462 U.S. 213 (1983) affirms the importance of transparency in the issuance of search warrants to ensure they are supported by probable cause and comply with constitutional requirements.
	8.	Decision-Making Process and Justification:
	•	Documents and communications that explain the decision-making process and justification for serving the no-knock warrant, including risk assessments and threat analyses.
	•	Legal Support: United States v. Leon, 468 U.S. 897 (1984) emphasizes the need for judicial oversight and transparency in warrant issuance to prevent abuses of power.
	9.	Training and Policies:
	•	Records of any training, guidelines, or policies provided to the officers involved, particularly those related to the execution of no-knock warrants and the use of force.
	•	Legal Support: Tennessee v. Garner, 471 U.S. 1 (1985) underscores the importance of clear policies and training regarding the use of deadly force by law enforcement.

Public Interest Justification:

The requested information is of significant public interest, particularly concerning the transparency of law enforcement activities and the use of force by police officers. Disclosure of these records will promote public understanding and facilitate informed community oversight.

Fees and Document Delivery:

I request a waiver of all fees associated with the processing of this request, as the disclosure serves the public interest significantly and enhances the understanding of government operations without any commercial benefit. I prefer to receive the documents electronically, via email or on a CD-ROM if digital transmission is not feasible.

Response Time and Legal Compliance:

As per the Maryland Public Information Act, I expect a response within the statutory timeframe. Failure to comply with this request may result in legal action to enforce the Act’s provisions. I remind you of your obligation to review this request carefully and to disclose all non-exempt portions of the requested records.

Notice of Publication:

Please be aware that all communications related to this request will be published on a public platform to ensure transparency.

Legal Action:

If necessary, I am prepared to initiate an Article 78 proceeding to compel compliance with the MPIA.

Conclusion:

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response and the provision of the requested records in accordance with the Maryland Public Information Act.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter
Investigative Journalist

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Threat Index - Shinzo Abe
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

For  US Department of State’s Diplomatic Security Service

I was seeking any records in your custody in relation to potential threats of assassination to the Former Japanese Prime Minster Shinzo Abe for the dates: 01/01/2022 to the current date.

I was also seeking any records in your custody related to the Former Prime Minister based on the announcement of his untimely murder.

The former prime minister was assassinated on 070822 during a speech in NARA.

Areas to search:
All available indices related to subject matter. 

Please release records on a rolling basis and include any future records added or cross-referenced to the subject until the request is completed.

EFOIA Request

Vaughn index is requested for any records claimed for exemption.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes

Request for fee waiver: Category Media public interest

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

William Fernandes

communications.subject: Ref: F-2022-10263, Freedom of Information Act Acknowledgement
communications.communication:
**THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.** Mr.Fernandes: This email acknowledgesreceipt of your July 11, 2022, Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) (5 U.S.C. §552) request received by the U.S. Department ofState, Office of Information Programs and Services on July 11, 2022, regarding any records in relation to potential threats of assassination to the Former Japanese Prime Minster Shinzo Abe for the dates: 01/01/2022 to the current date. Also, records related to the Former Prime Minister based on the announcement of his untimely murder.  Request is for release records on a rolling basis and include any future records added or cross-referenced to the subject until the request is completed (Date Range for Record Search: From 1/1/2022 To 7/11/2022).  Unless you advise otherwise, we will treat as non-responsive any compilations of publicly available news reports and any publicly available documents not created by the U.S. government, such as mass-distribution emails from news media.  This Office assigned your request the subject reference number and placed it in the complex processing track where it will beprocessed as quickly as possible. See 22CFR § 171.11(h). 
Yourequested a waiver for all fees associated with the processing of yourrequest. Please be advised this Officewill make a determination regarding a fee waiver at a later date. 
This Office willnot be able to respond within the 20 days provided by the statute due to“unusual circumstances.” See 5 U.S.C. §552(a)(6)(B)(i)-(iii). In this instance,the unusual circumstances include the need to search for and collect requestedrecords from other Department offices or Foreign Service posts. If you have any questions regarding yourrequest , would like to narrow the scope or arrange analternative time frame to speed its processing, or would like an estimated dateof completion, please contact our FOIA Requester Service Center or our FOIAPublic Liaison by email at FOIAstatus@state.gov or telephone at202-261-8484.  Additionally, youmay contact the Office of Government Information Services (OGIS) at theNational Archives and Records Administration to inquire about the FOIAmediation services they offer. Thecontact information for OGIS is as follows: Office of Government InformationServices, National Archives and Records Administration, 8601 Adelphi Road-OGIS,College Park, Maryland 20740-6001, email at ogis@nara.gov; telephone at202-741-5770; toll free at 1-877-684-6448; or facsimile at 202-741-5769. **THIS EMAIL BOX IS NOT MONITORED, PLEASE DO NOT REPLY TO THIS EMAIL.**

RE: Your CPRA Request dated December 5, 2023 (Index 3390)



We are responding to your California Public Records Act (CPRA) request received by email on December 5, 2023. You are seeking "any emails, documents, or policy papers mentioning 'The Berkeley Scanner' or 'Emilie Raguso' or 'berkeleyscanner.com'" from October 1, 2023 to December 5, 2023.



We have enclosed a document responsive to your request.  Regarding your request for emails, we will consult our County IT Department to extract potentially relevant correspondence using a word search and to review them for potential exemptions or privileges. This process can take substantial time.



Regarding your request for policy papers, we have no responsive documents.



We will give you a production update on January 31, 2024.


Very truly yours,


[Text  Description automatically generated with low confidence]

Catherine H. Kobal • Assistant District Attorney • Custodian of the Record

Law and Motion Division • 1225 Fallon St., Oakland, CA 94612

o. 510-272-6222

title: Elixir Labs Contract for Oregon Provider Management and Payment Platform

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Elixir Labs Contract for Oregon Provider Management and Payment Platform
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Contract awarded to Elixir Labs from the Provider Management Platform RFP,  #S-58100-00007532.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Toni Thompson

communications.subject: Oregon Public Records Law Request: Elixir Labs Contract for Oregon Provider Management and Payment Platform
communications.communication:
Good morning Toni,

We received an email request via the platform Muckrock for a public records request. The following was the body of the email:

“Pursuant to the Oregon Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:
Contract awarded to Elixir Labs from the Provider Management Platform RFP, #S-58100-00007532.
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.”

DELC’s public record request form can be found here: Department of Early Learning and Care : Contact Us : About Us : State of Oregon<https://www.oregon.gov/delc/about-us/pages/contact-us.aspx> .
The are also separate instructions for alternate submission forms. DELC’s public records request system allows us to accurately track and communicate regarding requests and the back and forth regarding the request. I look forward to hearing from you or seeing your submission soon.

In accordance with ORS 192.324(4)(a), the public body may establish fees reasonably calculated to reimburse the public body for the public body’s actual cost of making public records available, including costs for summarizing, compiling, or tailoring the public records, either in organization or media, to meet the request.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Best wishes,
[A picture containing graphics, cartoon  Description automatically generated]
Madison Buck (She/Her)​
Department of Early Learning and Care​
Public Records and Communication Specialist
DELC.PRRequest@DELC.oregon.gov<mailto:DELC.PRRequest@DELC.oregon.gov>
Website: Oregon.gov/DELC<https://protect-us.mimecast.com/s/4T6sCW6qNgs52KYX8Ix6GqA?domain=oregon.gov>​
Connect with DELC: Facebook<https://www.facebook.com/OREarlyLearning/> | Instagram<https://www.instagram.com/OREarlyLearning/> | YouTube<https://www.youtube.com/@OREarlyLearning> | LinkedIn<https://www.linkedin.com/company/OREarlyLearning/>

The Oregon Department of Early Learning and Care (DELC) fosters coordinated, culturally appropriate, and family-centered services that recognize and respect the strengths of children, families and early learning and care professionals. Our vision is that all children, families, early care and education professionals, and communities are supported and empowered to thrive.

Toni Thompson”

communications.subject: RE: Public Records Request Inquiry 908
communications.communication:
Good afternoon,

This is to conclude DELC’s response to your request date 12/03/2024 at 4:36 PM. Attached are three documents and one excel file.

Some of the information you’ve requested is exempt from disclosure pursuant to the following:

  *   ORS 192.345 Subsection (27): Information provided to, obtained by or used by a public body to authorize, originate, receive or authenticate a transfer of funds, including but not limited to a credit card number, payment card expiration date, password, financial institution account number and financial institution routing number
  *   ORS 192.377: A public body that is the custodian of or is otherwise in possession of information that was submitted to the public body in confidence and is not otherwise required by law to be submitted.
Please let me know if you have any concerns or questions regarding the records. Thank you and have a wonderful day.

Best wishes,

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: SFD Complaints
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The "Final Report" for all internal investigations in which the named employees were alleged to have violated "Social Media Policy for Local 27 Members – Hate Speech", whether sustained or not, since January 1, 2019.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

communications.subject: Fire - General :: C200123-100624
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Welcome to the City of Seattle Public Records Request Center (PRRC). Your request was received on October 06, 2024 and is appended below. 
 
The reference number for this request is C200123-100624. You will see this number in the title of any communications about this request. 
 
You will hear from a Public Disclosure Officer within five business days regarding the status of your request. 
 
Please visit the City of Seattle Public Records Request Center where you can manage your profile and access your request. Your login ID is: 174118-12422467@requests.muckrock.com 
 
If a Public Disclosure Officer submitted your public disclosure request into the PRRC on your behalf, please login and complete your new user account by following these steps: 
 
  * Access the Public Records Request Center 
  * Select 'Forgot my Password' 
  * Enter your 'Login ID' (email address) 
  * A temporary password will be sent to you via email 
  * Login with the temporary password 
You may now visit the PRRC 'My Records Request Center' anytime! 
 
Request C200123-100624:  
" To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

communications.subject: City of Seattle Public Records Request Center - Invoice Ready :: C200123-100624
communications.communication:
Dear Rose Terse, 
 
Records in response to your public disclosure request C200123-100624 received on October 06, 2024 are now available. The cost for the records is as follows: 
 
Invoice Number: INV24-C200123-1 
Total: $1.25 
 
To pay online, please follow these steps: 
 Please note that you will need to disable any pop-up blockers to make a payment using the system. 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Find this request: C200123-100624. 
  * Select the 'View Invoices' button. 
 
  * Opens a pop-up window showing your invoice: INV24-C200123-1. 
  * Click on the invoice and then the 'Pay Now' button. 
  * Continue processing your payment. 
  * Select 'Done'. 
  * Once the payment process is done, you are returned to the Public Records Request Center. 
  * After your payment is successful you will receive an email from our payments center. 
Once your payment has been approved, we will send you an email with instructions on how to download your records. Note that City staff must manually upload records. Records will be available one to two business days after payment. 
 
Please let your public disclosure officer (PDO) know if you are unable to pay online; your PDO will work with you on alternative ways to make your payment. 
 
You have 30 days from today's date to pay for your records. If the City does not receive your payment within this time period, your request will be considered abandoned, and you will need to submit a new request. 
 Please add seattle@mycusthelp.net to your E-mail contacts/address book to ensure delivery of the record center E-mails to your Inbox. (mailto:seattle@mycusthelp.net) 
This is an auto-generated email and has originated from an unmonitored email account. Please DO NOT REPLY.

communications.subject: Fire - General :: C200123-100624
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

Dear Rose Terse, 
The final report for the one investigation that is responsive to your request is now available to download in response to your request C200123-100624. Myself and several members of our HR staff went through all of our investigative records since 2019, and the investigation into former employee Steve Collins was the only investigation where the Social Media Policy was actually implicated. 
To download  the report: 
 
  * Navigate to the Public Records Request Center.
  * Select 'My Records Request Center'. 
  * Select 'View My Requests'. You may be asked to login. 
  * Select this request: C200123-100624. 
  * Select the 'View Files' button. 
  * You can download records individually or all at the same time by clicking 'Download All'. 
  *  Please save your record as you may only download it from the system three times. If you do not download your record within 30 days of request closure, the link to your record will expire. 
The Seattle Fire Department has now provided the responsive records. We consider your request closed and plan to take no further action to fulfill this request. If you have any follow-up questions or would like to initiate an administrative appeal under MDAR 17-0002 Section 6, please contact us within 10 business days after downloading your records, after which this request will no longer be monitored for communications. You may also seek judicial review of our response to your request for a period of one year, beginning as of the date of this message, consistent with RCW 42.56.550. 
Evan Ward 
Public Disclosure Officer 
Seattle Fire Department

communications.subject: Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: City contracts/agreements with fiscal intermediaries
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Michigan Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all contracts and/or grant agreements between City of Detroit departments or budgeted units, and fiscal sponsors (which are sometimes also referred to as fiscal intermediaries or nonprofit fiduciaries) since 2018.  

For context, Office of Chief Financial Officer Communications Manager Stephanie Davis said a nonprofit fiduciary is a philanthropic group city departments use to send funds for a particular initiative or purpose. Those funds are tied to a grant agreement outlining the duration, terms, etc. of the work. 

For example, the Mayor's Office-Mobility uses Eastside Community Network as a fiscal sponsor.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Laura Herberg

communications.subject: Fw: [EXTERNAL] Michigan Freedom of Information Act Request: City contracts/agreements with fiscal intermediaries
communications.communication:
This email serves as the City of Detroit’s response to the above-referenced matter. Your request was received at the City of Detroit Law Department Freedom of Information Act Section via facsimile or email, on August 1, 2024. Because your request was received by electronic transmission, pursuant to Section 5(1) of the Michigan Freedom of Information Act (the “Act”), MCL 15.235(1); it is deemed to have been received at the Law Department on the next business day, August 2, 2024.

Pursuant to Section 5(2) of the Act, MCL 15.235(2), the City’s response is due within five (5) business days. However, due to the nature and the scope of your request and the volume of the requests received by the City, we are extending the City’s response deadline by ten (10) additional business days in accordance with Section 5(2) (d) of the Act, MCL 15.235(2) (d). Therefore, your request will be granted, denied, or granted in part and denied in part on or before August 23, 2024.

Your request is being handled by Amanda Kelly. If you have questions regarding your request, or if you did not provide an email address in your request, please forward it to Amanda Kelly at kellya@detroitmi.gov<mailto:kellya@detroitmi.gov> to provide you a response more readily than by regular mail or fax. Mail and fax are not preferred at this time since they both require in-office support. We thank you in advance for your understanding.

title: Agency Roster (Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department)

communications.subject: Nevada Public Records Act Request: Agency Roster (Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Nevada Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Please provide records sufficient to show a current staff roster of all sworn employees with your agency.

Please include;
- first and last name of each employee with their corresponding;
- badge number
- employee identification number
- hire date
- rank or position
- assigned duty station/substation/precinct/location
- current salary

This request applies to ALL sworn Department employees, including those at substations.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Marcus Boyd

communications.subject: Public Record Request Submitted for Public Record Request - Marcus Boyd
communications.communication:
Hello Marcus Boyd,

Public Record Request Title


Public Record Request - Marcus Boyd  


Public Record Request #


NPR2024-0069977 


Name of Requestor


Marcus Boyd 


Status


Submitted 


Request Submitted Date


11/25/2024 5:00 PM 






Your Public Record Service Request has been successfully submitted. You will be notified by email if more information or payment is required and when your request is completed. The Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department - Public Records Unit hours of operation are 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding holidays, Juneteenth, Nevada Day, the day after Thanksgiving and December 24th.  Any public record requests made outside of normal business hours will be deemed received the next business day. At any time, you may monitor the status of your request by logging into your Public Records portal account.

***Please note that holidays that fall on a Saturday or Sunday will be observed the preceding Friday or the following Monday. There are 13 holidays that LVMPD observes throughout the year. Based on this information, adjust your request accordingly.

Public Request Portal | Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department (lvmpd.com)<https://www.lvmpd.com/i-want-to/file/public-request-portal>

Thank you,

Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department
400 S. Martin L. King Boulevard
Las Vegas, Nevada  89106
702-828-7489
Monday-Friday 8am to 5pm

The records you seek are not readily available and would be unduly
burdensome to gather, compile, redact, and produce. A public entity need not produce records that are not readily available and
would require research, compilation and redaction to produce. See Lunney v.
State, 418 P.3d 943, 954 (Ariz. Ct. App. 2017) (recognizing that the agency was
not required to respond to the burdensome request); Shehadeh v. Madigan, 996
N.E.2d 1243, 1249 (Ill. App. Ct. 2013) (holding that the Attorney General
satisfied its burden by explaining that its staff members would have to go
through all of the 9,200 potentially responsive documents by hand); Beckett v.
Serpas, 112 So.3d 348, 353 (La. App. Ct. 2013) (determining that segregating
10-years worth of files is unreasonably burdensome); Community Youth Athletic
Ctr. v. City of Nat’l City, 164 Cal.Rptr.3d 644, 676, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1425
(2013) (generally, an agency is not required to undertake extraordinarily
extensive or intrusive searches, and in general, the scope of an agency’s search
for public records need only be reasonably calculated to locate responsive
documents) .
